environment module¶

class environment.Environment(simulation_length: int, demand: demand_function.DemandFunction)¶

Bases: object

The backbone of the simulation - responsible for tying most other elements together

all_agents¶

Represents a list of all agents partaking in the simulation

Type

list[Agent]

hist_sales_made¶

The list represents the time slice of the simulation For a time slice we can use the inner list to find how many sales an agent made using their index in all_agents.

Type

list[list[int]]

hist_set_prices¶

The list represents the time slice of the simulation For a time slice we can use the list to find what price an agent set using their index in all_agents.

(These are separate attributes since we need to be able to give an agent

hist_set_prices without letting them see hist_sales_made)

Type

list[list[float]]

simulation_length¶

Used to keep track of when the simulation is “complete”. Must be positive

Type

int

time_step¶

Used to keep track of the simulation time elapsed. Must be positive

Type

int

demand¶

Reposible for generating a demand function (interchangeable)

Type

DemandFunction

add_agent(agent: agent.Agent) → None¶

Adds an agent to the simulation. Separated from constructor to allow mid-simulation entries

Parameters

agent (Agent) – The agent to be added

get_results() → tuple[list[list[float]], list[list[int]]]¶

Allows post-simulation analysis to be performed on sales figures and numbers

Returns

  • self.hist_set_prices (list[list[float]]) – The list represents the time slice of the simulation For a time slice we can use the inner list to find how many sales an agent made using their index in all_agents.

  • self.hist_sales_made (list[list[int]]) – The list represents the time slice of the simulation For a time slice we can use the list to find what price an agent set using their index in all_agents.

run_next_time_step() → None¶

Runs a time step for the simulation and appends results to the historic data

simulation
